Lower Classes Hold
Banquets Peacefully
Freshman and Sophomore Affairs
Undisturbed for First Time

For the first time in the history
of lower class banquets, the freshmen held their annual feast at the
Hotel Kernan on Saturday night,
absolutely undisturbed and with no
encircling cordon of protecting police. War was officially declared
off at 5.30, two hours before the beginning of the dinner. At this time
all sophomores held as prisoners
were doomed to remain so and be
taken to the opposing class feed,
while freshman officers were given
the opportunity to return to their
cohorts and preside over the sumptuous repast.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 3, 1928

FARINHOLT AND FINN
LOST TO TWELVE
Services of Larkin Farinholt
and Raymond Finn, two regulars on last year's lacrosse
team, may be lost to the twelve
this season. Farinholt underwent an operation for appendicitis last Thursday and will
be definitely out of the line-up
for the rest of the season. Finn,
who was struck in the eye by a
ball last week, was also at the
hospital for several days. He
will be unable to play for the
first part of the schedule, at
least.
Although the team is well
supplied with reserve material
in both midfield attack and
goal positions, it is expected
that these unforeseen losses
will be keenly felt.

HALL HEARINGS
Spring has come not without its
various effects. Everywhere in the
vicinity of the Hall one can see
verdant signs. Baseball is the most
significant. Every day there are several of the boys on the quadrangle
catching. In fact the spirit of the
game has gotten them so badly that
they tried it on Sunday. Sergeant
Frank put a quick stop to this with
threats of backing up the "wagon."

The batteries for the Hall baseball
aggregation have been "warming up"
all winter on their curves. The organized practice was held every Friday after lunch. When baseballs
were impractical they used the apples served at lunch on Friday.
These served a double purpose in
that they provided good practice
and that they could be used to bear
out grudges.

It has been observed that more
and more "automobiles" have come
into use lately. Within the last few
days an old Ford appeared from
nowhere running around the campus
with 1925 license plates. It runs
perfectly downhill. It was also
noticed that one night an old Chevrolet with half a rear mudguard and
no top went out and returned with
a rather ill-fitting top and engine
hood.

B Entry has lost its claim to being the noisiest entry in the Hall.
When it began to quiet down C began to become more active, with the
result that it now holds the crown.
It seems that the occupants work in
shifts, the first of which begins at
11 P. M. and these continue until
about 2 A. M. The main duties of
the men on the shifts are to shout
as loudly as possible in the halls, run
noisily up and down the stairs and
occasionally stage a pillow or water
fight.

Psychology I has played havoc
with the greater part of the residents for the past week. Hypnotism has become the chief pastime
of the boys. Sessions are held in a
number of the rooms from seven
until midnight. These provide for
a great deal of enjoyment at no cost.
For information apply to Professor
Rosenthal or his assistants.

With the end of the month drawing near, money has, as usual, become exceedingly scarce. Most of
the residents are at their wits' ends
as to how to pay for their "dates"
to the Lyric.

Many of the residents have been
having an extremely hard time getting telephone calls through to Goucher residence halls. We suggest
that the Goucher authorities see that
more phones are installed, especially
in Glitner.

At noon time, Tuesday, the residents were entertained by a "strolling troubadour" who sang in the
"quad." We wonder if he got a free
meal.

As to the plan of naming the
entries, we wish to say that "B"
entry will never be anything else but
"B." There's a tradition in that letter.

Black and Blue Jay adherents
were given a thrill yesterday. The
business department was set to
talking, the editorial board to grinning, and the whole staff to congratulating the postal service. No,
a carload of good copy was not
dumped at the door, nor did the
printer decide to set up and print
the last two issues gratis, nor did
the NEWS-LETTER promise to refrain from certain harsh criticisms.
What, then, could cause all of the
excitement? Had the president decided to name the C. E. Hall after
the present editors? Had the Gilman Memorial Room been turned
over to the staff as offices, or had
the deal officially sanctioned the Jay
as a needed New Plan publication?
No, none of these. What then?
The cause of the disturbance was a
minor matter, a little slip of paper
a few inches wide and hardly more
in length.

Along one edge were little perforations. At the top of this slip
of paper was printed a few words
in English. At the bottom was a
few more in the same language.
The space in between was filled out
with typewriting. At the extreme
bottom on the right-hand side there
was an ink mark, hardly more than
a scratch, yet, oh so necessary!
The printing at the top was of the
name of some trust company in
Cleveland. The name at the bottom
was Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War in the Cabinet of
Woodrow Wilson. The check—for
this slip of paper was a check—was
in payment for a year's subscription
to the Blue Jay.
The Jay members say that the
Secretary has always been noted for
his discernment and sagacity. The
staff of the sister publication are
trying to reconcile this statement
with the check.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir—A crack in a tradition,
as in a building, will soon cause the
whole rigid structure to come tumbling down.
It is thus with freshman-sophomore hostilities. Year after year
the two classes fought each other
with varying degrees of violence
simply because it was expected of
them to do so. The rivalry became
a habit which afforded excellent occasional outlets for pure animal spirits and the instincts of savagery that
survive from jungle days. These
outbreaks, from time to time, are
looked upon by the general public
with tolerance because the intermittent blowing off of steam became
traditional.
Last year the annual banquet season eruption reached the highest and
most explosive climax of all, when
attacking sophomores at the Annapolis freshman affair got mixed up
with the clubs of the town police
after making a glorious mess of
things in the armory.
The affair got into the front pages
of the newspapers. There was a
great deal of unfavorable criticism,
and more of cynical comment on the
rowdyism of many undergraduates
on the road to higher education.
Reaction came—the law of the
pendulum—and the Student Council this year passed restricting rules,
the first fissure in the structure of
tradition. After a sudden but brief
outburst of fighting on the opening
day of the season and a few miscellaneous splutterings, the number of
those attracted by the battle cries of
the classes diminished considerably,
and it remained with a belligerent
few to carry on with the banner of
custom.
This is a marked turning against
this sort of horseplay, which is a
healthy sign of the future. In a
few years artificial class struggles
will be relegated to the graveyard of
the out-of-date and few will mourn
over the corpse.
The same tendencies to a disappearance of eruptions is at work in
other lines of "social" activity. The
recent powwow marked the beginning of the end of drunken brawls
on the campus, where certain students were unable to drink like gentlemen and became disgustingly seasick or hopelessly boorish.
The Student .Council is the organization which can most effectively get rid of unpleasant affairs
that leave bad feeling behind them.
The council has but to drive in the
entering wedge by a few minor rulings and time will hasten the end.

cohorts and preside over the sumptuous repast.

hospital for several days. He
will be unable to play for the
first part of the schedule, at
least.

supplied with reserve material
in both midfield attack and
goal positions, it is expected
that these unforeseen losses
will be keenly felt.

HALL HEARINGS
Spring has come not without its
various effects. Everywhere in the
vicinity of the Hall one can see
verdant signs. Baseball is the most
significant. Every day there are several of the boys on the quadrangle
catching. In fact the spirit of the
game has gotten them so badly that
they tried it on Sunday. Sergeant
Frank put a quick stop to this with
threats of backing up the "wagon."

The batteries for the Hall baseball
aggregation have been "warming up"
all winter on their curves. The organized practice was held every Friday after lunch. When baseballs
were impractical they used the apples served at lunch on Friday.
These served a double purpose in
that they provided good practice
and that they could be used to bear
out grudges.

It has been observed that more
and more "automobiles" have come
into use lately. Within the last few
days an old Ford appeared from
nowhere running around the campus
with 1925 license plates. It runs
perfectly downhill. It was also
noticed that one night an old Chevrolet with half a rear mudguard and
no top went out and returned with
a rather ill-fitting top and engine
hood.

B Entry has lost its claim to being the noisiest entry in the Hall.
When it began to quiet down C began to become more active, with the
result that it now holds the crown.
It seems that the occupants work in
shifts, the first of which begins at
11 P. M. and these continue until
about 2 A. M. The main duties of
the men on the shifts are to shout
as loudly as possible in the halls, run
noisily up and down the stairs and
occasionally stage a pillow or water
fight.

Psychology I has played havoc
with the greater part of the residents for the past week. Hypnotism has become the chief pastime
of the boys. Sessions are held in a
number of the rooms from seven
until midnight. These provide for
a great deal of enjoyment at no cost.
For information apply to Professor
Rosenthal or his assistants.

With the end of the month drawing near, money has, as usual, become exceedingly scarce. Most of
the residents are at their wits' ends
as to how to pay for their "dates"
to the Lyric.

Many of the residents have been
having an extremely hard time getting telephone calls through to Goucher residence halls. We suggest
that the Goucher authorities see that
more phones are installed, especially
in Glitner.

At noon time, Tuesday, the residents were entertained by a "strolling troubadour" who sang in the
"quad." We wonder if he got a free
meal.

As to the plan of naming the
entries, we wish to say that "B"
entry will never be anything else but
"B." There's a tradition in that letter.

SENDS JAY STAFF INTO HIGH GLEE
Black and Blue Jay adherents
were given a thrill yesterday. The
business department was set to
talking, the editorial board to grinning, and the whole staff to congratulating the postal service. No,
a carload of good copy was not
dumped at the door, nor did the
printer decide to set up and print
the last two issues gratis, nor did
the NEWS-LETTER promise to refrain from certain harsh criticisms.
What, then, could cause all of the
excitement? Had the president decided to name the C. E. Hall after
the present editors? Had the Gilman Memorial Room been turned
over to the staff as offices, or had
the deal officially sanctioned the Jay
as a needed New Plan publication?
No, none of these. What then?
The cause of the disturbance was a
minor matter, a little slip of paper
a few inches wide and hardly more
in length.

Along one edge were little perforations. At the top of this slip
of paper was printed a few words
in English. At the bottom was a
few more in the same language.
The space in between was filled out
with typewriting. At the extreme
bottom on the right-hand side there
was an ink mark, hardly more than
a scratch, yet, oh so necessary!
The printing at the top was of the
name of some trust company in
Cleveland. The name at the bottom
was Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War in the Cabinet of
Woodrow Wilson. The check—for
this slip of paper was a check—was
in payment for a year's subscription
to the Blue Jay.
The Jay members say that the
Secretary has always been noted for
his discernment and sagacity. The
staff of the sister publication are
trying to reconcile this statement
with the check.

To the Editor of the News-Letter:
Dear Sir—A crack in a tradition,
as in a building, will soon cause the
whole rigid structure to come tumbling down.
It is thus with freshman-sophomore hostilities. Year after year
the two classes fought each other
with varying degrees of violence
simply because it was expected of
them to do so. The rivalry became
a habit which afforded excellent occasional outlets for pure animal spirits and the instincts of savagery that
survive from jungle days. These
outbreaks, from time to time, are
looked upon by the general public
with tolerance because the intermittent blowing off of steam became
traditional.
Last year the annual banquet season eruption reached the highest and
most explosive climax of all, when
attacking sophomores at the Annapolis freshman affair got mixed up
with the clubs of the town police
after making a glorious mess of
things in the armory.
The affair got into the front pages
of the newspapers. There was a
great deal of unfavorable criticism,
and more of cynical comment on the
rowdyism of many undergraduates
on the road to higher education.
Reaction came—the law of the
pendulum—and the Student Council this year passed restricting rules,
the first fissure in the structure of
tradition. After a sudden but brief
outburst of fighting on the opening
day of the season and a few miscellaneous splutterings, the number of
those attracted by the battle cries of
the classes diminished considerably,
and it remained with a belligerent
few to carry on with the banner of
custom.
This is a marked turning against
this sort of horseplay, which is a
healthy sign of the future. In a
few years artificial class struggles
will be relegated to the graveyard of
the out-of-date and few will mourn
over the corpse.
The same tendencies to a disappearance of eruptions is at work in
other lines of "social" activity. The
recent powwow marked the beginning of the end of drunken brawls
on the campus, where certain students were unable to drink like gentlemen and became disgustingly seasick or hopelessly boorish.
The Student .Council is the organization which can most effectively get rid of unpleasant affairs
that leave bad feeling behind them.
The council has but to drive in the
entering wedge by a few minor rulings and time will hasten the end.
